analyzed: śrīḥ
translated: Śrī
The second bouquet in the Nyāyakusumāñjali.

analyzed: tat evam sāmānyatas  alaukike hatau tad sādhanena avaśyam
translated: Thus, in general,

analyzed: bhavitavyam
translated: having established the non-worldly destruction, it must necessarily be accomplished by its means.

analyzed: na ca tat śakyam asmat ādibhiḥ draṣṭum
translated: And that cannot be seen by us and others.

original: na cādṛṣṭena vyavahāraḥ tato lokottaraḥ sarvānubhāvī sambhāvyate /🔽ku / / nanu nityanirdeṣavedadvārako yogakarmasiddhasarvajñadvārako vā dharmasampradāyaḥ syāt /
analyzed: na ca adṛṣṭena vyavahāraḥ tatas loka uttaraḥ sarva anubhāvī sambhāvyate
translated: And there is no usage without being seen. Therefore, the supramundane, all-pervading [means of valid cognition] is possible.

analyzed: kim parameśvara kalpanayā iti ced
translated: But isn't the tradition of Dharma to be through the eternal and faultless Veda, or through the omniscient one who has accomplished yoga and karma? What is the use of positing the Supreme Lord?

analyzed: atrā ucyate pramāyāḥ paratantra tvāt sarga pralaya sambhavāt
translated: To this it is said: Because valid knowledge is dependent on something else, and because creation and dissolution are possible,
in anything else there is no confidence, so another means [of valid knowledge] is not possible.

original: ku / / tathā hi / / /pramājñānahetvatiriktahetvadhīnā kāryatve sati tadviśeṣatvāt apramāvat /
analyzed: tathā hi pramā jñāna hetu atirikta hetu adhīnā kārya tve sati tad viśeṣa tvāt apramā vat
translated: Thus, indeed... Because it is an effect, dependent on a cause other than the cause of knowledge, and because it is a particular case of that, like invalid knowledge.

analyzed: yadi ca tāvat mātra adhīnā bhavet
translated: And if it were dependent on just that much,

analyzed: apramā api pramā eva bhavet
translated: invalid knowledge would also be valid knowledge.

analyzed: asti hi tatra jñāna hetuḥ
translated: For there is a cause of knowledge there.

analyzed: anyathā jñānam api sā na syāt
translated: Otherwise, even knowledge would not be that.

original: ku / / jñānatve 'pyatiriktadoṣānupraveśādaprameti cet evaṃ tarhi doṣābhāvamadhikamāsādya pramāpi jāyeta /
analyzed: jñāna tve pi atirikta doṣa anupraveśāt apramā iti ced evam tarhi doṣa abhāvam adhikam āsādya pramā api jāyeta
translated: If it be said that, even though it is knowledge, it is not valid cognition because it is associated with an additional defect, then, in that case, valid cognition also would be produced on the acquisition of the absence of defects as an additional factor.

analyzed: niyamena tad apekṣaṇāt
translated: Because it invariably requires that.

analyzed: astu doṣa abhāvaḥ dhikaḥ
translated: Let the absence of defects be an additional factor.

analyzed: bhāvaḥ tu na iṣyate iti ced bhavet api evam
translated: If it be said that existence is not accepted, it would be so.

analyzed: yadi niyamena doṣaiḥ bhāva rūpaiḥ eva bhavitavyam
translated: If it were invariably to be by the defects themselves in the form of existence.

analyzed: na tu evam viśeṣa adarśana ādeḥ abhāvasya api doṣa tvāt
translated: But it is not so, because the absence of the non-perception of difference, etc. is also a defect.

analyzed: katham anyathā tatas saṃśaya viparyayau
translated: Otherwise, how can doubt and error arise from that?

original: tatastadabhāvo bhāva eveti kathaṃ sa neṣyate /
analyzed: tatas tad abhāvaḥ bhāvaḥ evā iti katham sa nā iṣyate
translated: Then, how can the absence of that be not accepted as existence itself?

original: ku / / syādetat śabde tāvat vipralipsādayo bhāvā eva doṣāḥ /🔽tatastadabhāve svata eva śābdī prameti cet na anumānādau liṅgaviparyāsādīnāṃ
analyzed: syāt etat śabde tāvat vipralipsā ādayaḥ bhāvāḥ eva doṣāḥ  tatas tad abhāve svatas eva śābdī pramā iti ced na anumāna ādau liṅga viparyāsa ādīnām
translated: If it be said that in the case of verbal testimony, the defects are indeed the positive factors such as deception, etc.,🔽and therefore, in the absence of those, verbal testimony is valid by itself, it is not so, because in inference, etc., even the positive factors such as the reversal of the reason, etc.

analyzed: bhāvānām api doṣa tve tad abhāva mātreṇa pramā anutpatteḥ
translated: are defects, and valid cognition is not produced merely by the absence of those.

analyzed: anyatra yathā tathā astu
translated: Let it be so in some other case.

original: śabde tu vipralipsādyabhāve vaktṛguṇāpekṣā nāstī'ti cenna guṇābhāve tadapramāṇyasya vaktṛdoṣāpekṣā nāstīti viparyayasyāpi tulyatvāt /
analyzed: śabde tu vipralipsā ādi abhāve vaktṛ guṇa apekṣā na asti iti ced na guṇa abhāve tad apramāṇyasya vaktṛ doṣa apekṣā na asti iti viparyayasya api
translated: But if it be said that in the case of a word there is no need of the speaker's qualities, because there is no possibility of deception, etc., on the part of the word,—we reply: No; because the contrary is equally true, that in the absence of qualities there is no need of the speaker's faults in order to make the word unauthoritative.

original: aprāmāṇyaṃ prati doṣāṇāmanvayavyatirekau sta iti cenna prāmāṇyaṃ pratyapi guṇānāṃ tayoḥ sattvāt /
analyzed: aprāmāṇyam prati doṣāṇām anvaya vyatirekau staḥ iti ced na prāmāṇyam prati api guṇānām tayoḥ sattvāt
translated: But if it be said that the presence and absence of faults are the cause of the presence and absence of unauthoritativeness,—we reply: No; because the presence and absence of qualities are the cause of the presence and absence of authoritativeness.

analyzed: pauruṣeya viṣaye iyam astu vyavasthā
translated: But let this distinction hold in the case of words that are human.

original: apauruṣeye tu doṣanivṛttyaiva prāmāṇyamiti cenna guṇanivṛttyāprāmāṇyasyāpi sambhavāt /
analyzed: apauruṣeye tu doṣa nivṛttyā eva prāmāṇyam iti ced na guṇa nivṛttyā aprāmāṇyasya api sambhavāt
translated: But if it be said that in the case of words that are not human, authoritativeness is due to the mere absence of faults,—we reply: No; because unauthoritativeness may also be due to the mere absence of qualities.

original: tasyā aprāmāṇyaṃ prati sāmarthyaṃ nopalabdhamiti cet doṣanivṛtteḥ prāmāṇyaṃ prati kva sāmarthyamupalabdham /
analyzed: tasyāḥ aprāmāṇyam prati sāmarthyam nā upalabdham iti ced doṣa nivṛtteḥ prāmāṇyam prati kva sāmarthyam upalabdham
translated: But if it be said that the absence of qualities has not been found to be the cause of unauthoritativeness,—we reply: Where has the absence of faults been found to be the cause of authoritativeness?

analyzed: loka vacasi iti ced tulyam
translated: But if it be said that it is found in the case of human words,—we reply: The same is true.

original: tadaprāmāṇye doṣā eva kāraṇam /🔽gumanivṛttistvavarjanīyasiddhasannidhiriti cet prāmāṇyaṃ prati guṇeṣvapi tulyametat /
analyzed: tad aprāmāṇye doṣāḥ eva kāraṇam  guma nivṛttiḥ tu avarjanīya siddha sannidhiḥ iti ced prāmāṇyam prati guṇeṣu api tulyam etat
translated: In the case of unauthoritativeness, faults are the cause.🔽But if it be said that the absence of qualities is a necessary concomitant of the absence of faults,—we reply: The same is true of qualities in the case of authoritativeness.

original: guṇānāṃ doṣotsāraṇaprayuktaḥ sannidhiriti cet doṣāṇāmapi guṇotsāraṇaprayukta ityastu /
analyzed: guṇānām doṣa utsāraṇa prayuktaḥ sannidhiḥ iti ced doṣāṇām api guṇa utsāraṇa prayuktaḥ iti astu
translated: But if it be said that the presence of qualities is due to the removal of faults,—we reply: Let the presence of faults be due to the removal of qualities.

original: niḥsvabhāvatvamevamapauruṣeyasya vedasya syāditi cet ātmānamupālabhasva /🔽tasmāt yathā dveṣarāgābhāvāvinābhāve 'pi rāgadveṣayo
analyzed: niḥsvabhāva tvam evam apauruṣeyasya vedasya syāt iti ced ātmānam upālabhasva  tasmāt yathā dveṣa rāga abhāva avinābhāve pi rāga dveṣayoḥ
translated: If it is argued that thus the Veda would be devoid of any nature if it is not of human origin, then you should reproach yourself.🔽Therefore, just as in the absence of hatred and attachment, the efforts for engagement and disengagement are caused by attachment and hatred,
because of the restriction of conformity with attachment and hatred,

analyzed: na tu nivṛtti prayatnaḥ dveṣa hetukaḥ
translated: the effort for disengagement is not caused by hatred.

original: pravṛttiprayatnastu satyapi rāgānuvidhāne dveṣābhāvahetuka iti vibhago yujyate /
analyzed: pravṛtti prayatnaḥ tu sati api rāga anuvidhāne dveṣa abhāva hetukaḥ iti vibhagaḥ yujyate
translated: But the effort for engagement, even though conforming with attachment, is caused by the absence of hatred. Thus the distinction is proper.

analyzed: viśeṣa abhāvāt tathā prakṛte pi
translated: In the present case also, it is so because there is no difference.

original: ku / / tathāpi vedānāmapauruṣeyatve siddhe apetavaktṛdoṣatvādeva prāmāṇyaṃ setsyati /
analyzed: tathā api vedānām apauruṣeya tve siddhe apeta vaktṛ doṣa tvāt eva prāmāṇyam setsyati
translated: Even so, if the non-human origin of the Vedas is established, their validity will be established just by the absence of defects in the speaker.

original: tataḥ siddhe prāmāṇye guṇābhāve 'pi taditi doṣābhāva eva hetuḥ /
analyzed: tatas siddhe prāmāṇye guṇa abhāve pi tat iti doṣa abhāvaḥ eva hetuḥ
translated: Then, when validity is established, even in the absence of excellences, it is so. Thus the absence of defects alone is the reason.

original: akāraṇaṃ guṇā iti cenna apetavaktṛguṇatvena satpratipakṣatvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: akāraṇam guṇāḥ iti ced na apeta vaktṛ guṇa tvena sat pratipakṣa tva prasaṅgāt
translated: If it is argued that excellences are not the cause, it is not so, because it would lead to the undesirable consequence of being contradicted by the fact of the Vedas being devoid of excellences in the speaker.

analyzed: svatas eva prāmāṇya niścayaḥ
translated: The ascertainment of validity is from itself alone.

analyzed: kim tu śaṅkā mātram anena apanīyate
translated: But by this, mere doubt is removed.

analyzed: doṣa nibandhana tvāt tasya tad abhāve bhāvāt
translated: Because it is based on defects, it is absent in their absence.

analyzed: atas na idam anumāna vat anumānam
translated: Therefore, this is not inference like inference.

analyzed: sat pratisādhanīkartum ucitam iti ced na guṇa nivṛtti nibandhanāyāḥ śaṅkāyāḥ sulabha tvāt
translated: If it be said that it is proper to refute the true [cognition], no [says the siddhāntin]; because the doubt that has for its basis the cessation of the excellences is easily produced.

original: tasyāḥ kevalāyā aprāmāṇyaṃ pratyanaṅgatvānna śaṅketi cet doṣanivṛtterapi kevalāyāḥ prāmāṇyaṃpratyanaṅgatvānna tayā śaṅkānivṛttiriti tulyamiti
analyzed: tasyāḥ kevalāyāḥ aprāmāṇyam prati anaṅga tvāt na śaṅkā iti ced doṣa nivṛtteḥ api kevalāyāḥ prāmāṇyam prati anaṅga tvāt na tayā śaṅkā nivṛttiḥ iti tulyam iti
translated: If it be said that that [doubt] by itself is not a condition for invalidity and therefore does not cause doubt, [we reply:] the same may be said of the cessation of the defects [which you affirm to be a condition for validity]; that by itself is not a condition for validity and therefore the cessation of doubt does not result from it.

original: ku / / evaṃ prāmāṇyaṃ parato jñāyate anabhyāsadaśāyāṃ sāṃśayikatvāt aprāmāṇyavat /
analyzed: evam prāmāṇyam paratas jñāyate anabhyāsa daśāyām sāṃśayika tvāt aprāmāṇya vat
translated: Thus validity is known through something other [than the cognition itself], because there is doubt in the state of non-habit, as in the case of invalidity.

analyzed: yadi tu svatas jñāyeta
translated: But if it were known through itself,

analyzed: kadācid api prāmāṇya saṃśayaḥ na syāt jñāna tva saṃśaya vat
translated: there would never be doubt regarding validity, just as there is no doubt regarding the nature of cognition.

analyzed: niścite tad anavakāśāt  nahi sādhaka bādhaka pramā a sādhaka pramā
translated: Because when that [validity] is ascertained, there is no opportunity for [doubt].

analyzed: samāna dharma ādi darśanāt eva asau
translated: For that [doubt] does not arise merely from seeing similarity, etc., without the absence of the cognition of the means of valid knowledge and the means of refutation.

analyzed: tathā sati tad anuccheda prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if it were so, it would follow that it would never cease.

original: ku / / atha pramāṇavadapramāṇe 'pi tatpratyayadarśanāt viśeṣādarśanāt bhavati śaṅketyabhiprāyaḥ tat kiṃ pramāṇajñānopalambhe 'pi na tatprāmāṇyamupalabdham /
analyzed: atha pramāṇa vat apramāṇe tad pratyaya darśanāt viśeṣa adarśanāt bhavati śaṅkā iti abhiprāyaḥ tat kim pramāṇa jñāna upalambhe na tat prāmāṇyam upalabdham
translated: But if the intention is that doubt arises because the conditions for [valid cognition] are seen in invalid cognition also, and because no distinction is seen [between valid and invalid cognition], is the validity of that [cognition] not apprehended even when the cognition of valid cognition is apprehended?

analyzed: pramāṇa jñānam eva vā na upalabdham
translated: Or, the knowledge of the means of valid knowledge itself is not apprehended.

analyzed: ādye katham svatas prāmāṇya grahaḥ
translated: In the first case, how is the apprehension of intrinsic validity?

analyzed: pratyaya pratītau api tad apratīteḥ
translated: Because even when the cognition of the condition is obtained, that [validity] is not apprehended.

analyzed: dvitīye katham tatra śaṅkā
translated: In the second case, how is there doubt about that?

analyzed: dharmiṇaḥ eva anupalabdheḥ iti
translated: Because the very substratum is not apprehended.

original: ku / / yadapi jhaṭiti pracuratarasamarthapravṛttyanyathānupapattyā svataḥ prāmāṇyamucyate tadapi nāsti /
analyzed: yat api jhaṭiti pracuratara samartha pravṛtti anyathā anupapattyā svatas prāmāṇyam ucyate tat api na asti
translated: As for what is said about intrinsic validity by the non-apprehension of any other cause of the sudden and abundant occurrence of effective action, that too is not so.

analyzed: anyathā eva upapatteḥ  jhaṭiti pravṛttiḥ hi jhaṭiti tad kāraṇa upanipātam antareṇa anupapadyamānā
translated: Because it is possible in another way.🔽For the sudden occurrence, being impossible without the sudden occurrence of its cause,

analyzed: tam ākṣipet
translated: would imply that [cause].

analyzed: pracura pravṛttiḥ api sva kāraṇa prācuryam
translated: And the abundant occurrence also implies the abundance of its cause.

analyzed: icchā ca pravṛtteḥ kāraṇam
translated: And desire is the cause of occurrence.

analyzed: tad kāraṇam api iṣṭa abhyupāya tā jñānam  tat api tad jātīya tva liṅga anubhava prabhavam
translated: And that cause is the knowledge of the means to the desired [object].🔽And that too arises from the experience of the inferential mark of belonging to that class.

analyzed: saḥ pi indriya sannikarṣa ādi janmā
translated: And that too is born from the contact of the sense organ and so on.

analyzed: na tu prāmāṇya grahasya kvacid api upayogaḥ
translated: But the apprehension of validity is not of any use anywhere.

original: upayoge vā svata eveti kuta etat /
analyzed: upayoge vā svatas eva iti kutas etat
translated: Or if it is of use, then how is it that it is intrinsic?

original: tataḥ samarthapravṛttiprācuryamapi prāmāṇyaprācuryāttadgrahaṇaprācuryādvā svatastvaṃ tu tasya kvopayujyate /
analyzed: tatas samartha pravṛtti prācuryam api prāmāṇya prācuryāt tad grahaṇa prācuryāt vā svatastvam tu tasya kva upayujyate
translated: Then, even the abundance of effective activity is due to the abundance of validity or to the abundance of its apprehension. But where is the use of intrinsic nature?

original: na hi pipāsūnāṃ jhaṭiti pracurā samarthā ca pravṛttirambhasīti pipāsopaśamanaśaktistasya pratyakṣā syāt /
analyzed: na hi pipāsūnām jhaṭiti pracurā samarthā ca pravṛttiḥ ambhasi iti pipāsā upaśamana śaktiḥ tasya pratyakṣā syāt
translated: For the thirsty, the activity is not immediately abundant and effective with regard to water, so the capacity to alleviate thirst would not be directly perceived in it.

analyzed: syāt etat prāmāṇya grahe sati sarvam etat upapadyate
translated: If it is argued that all this is possible only when there is apprehension of validity,

original: sa ca svato yadi na syāt /
analyzed: sa ca svatas yadi na syāt
translated: and that if it were not intrinsic,

original: na syādeva / parataḥpakṣasyānavasthāduḥsthatvāditi cet na tadagrahe 'pyarthasandehādapi sarvasyopapatteḥ /
analyzed: na syāt eva paratas pakṣasya anavasthā duḥstha tvāt iti ced na tad agrahe pi artha sandehāt api sarvasya upapatteḥ
translated: it would not exist at all, because of the difficulty of the regress in the alternative of extrinsicness, - this is not so, because everything is possible even without its apprehension, due to doubt regarding the object.

analyzed: na ca anavasthau api
translated: And there is no regress.

analyzed: prāmāṇyasya avaśya jñeya tva anabhyupagamāt
translated: Because the necessity of knowing validity is not accepted.

analyzed: anyathā svataḥpakṣe pi sā syāt
translated: Otherwise, it would be so even in the case of intrinsicness.

analyzed: liṅgam niścitam eva niścāyakam
translated: If it is argued that only a certain definite mark is the determiner,

original: tatastanniścayārthamavaśyaṃ liṅgāntarāpekṣāyāmanavastheti cet tatkimanupapadyamānor'thaḥ aniścita eva svopapādakamākṣipati /
analyzed: tatas tad niścaya artham avaśyam liṅga antara apekṣāyām anavasthā iti ced tat kim anupapadyamāna ūrthaḥ aniścitaḥ eva sva upapādakam ākṣipati
translated: and therefore, in order to ascertain that, there is necessarily dependence on another mark, leading to regress, - then, does an object that is not possible, being uncertain itself, imply what establishes it,

analyzed: yena anavasthā na syāt
translated: so that there would be no regress?

original: pratyakṣeṇa tasya niścayāttasya ca sattayaiva niścāyakatvānnaivamiti cet mamāpi pratyakṣeṇa liṅganiścayāt tasya ca sattayaiva niścāyakatvānnaivamiti
analyzed: pratyakṣeṇa tasya niścayāt tasya ca sattayā eva niścāyaka tvāt na evam iti ced mama api pratyakṣeṇa liṅga niścayāt tasya ca sattayā eva niścāyaka tvāt na evam iti
translated: If it be said that this is not so, because the existence of the object is ascertained by perception, and because the existence of the object is ascertained by perception itself, the same may be said of me also, because the existence of the mark is ascertained by perception, and because the existence of the mark is ascertained by perception itself.

analyzed: tulyam
translated: It is the same.

original: yaḥsyāditi cet anupapadyamānārthajñānaprāmāṇyāniścaye kathaṃ tanniścaya iti tulyam /
analyzed: yaḥ syāt iti ced anupapadyamāna artha jñāna prāmāṇya aniścaye katham tad niścayaḥ iti tulyam
translated: If it be said that, if the validity of the knowledge of the mark be not ascertained, how can the existence of the mark be ascertained from it, the same may be said, viz., if the validity of the knowledge of an object not already known be not ascertained, how can that object be ascertained?

original: na hi niścayena svaprāmāṇyaniścayena vā viṣayaṃ niścāyayati pratyakṣam /🔽api tu svasattayetyuktamiti cet tulyam /
analyzed: na hi niścayena sva prāmāṇya niścayena vā viṣayam niścāyayati pratyakṣam  api tu sva sattayā iti uktam iti ced tulyam
translated: For perception does not ascertain the object either by ascertaining its own validity or by not ascertaining it.🔽But it does so by its own existence. If it be said that the same may be said of the knowledge of the mark,

original: ku / / tathāpi yadi tat liṅgābhāsaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tathā api yadi tat liṅga ābhāsaḥ syāt
translated: still, if that be a false mark,

original: tadā kā vārteti cet anupapadyamāno 'pyartho yadyābhāsaḥ syāt /
analyzed: tadā kā vārttā iti ced anupapadyamānaḥ pi arthaḥ yadi ābhāsaḥ syāt
translated: what then? If an object not already known be a false object,

analyzed: tadā kā vārttā iti tulyam
translated: what then? The same may be said.

analyzed: saḥ pi prāmāṇyam ākṣipati iti utsargaḥ
translated: That also casts doubt on the validity. This is the general rule.

original: sa ca kvacidvādhakenāpodyata iti cet liṅge 'pyevamiti tulyam /
analyzed: sa ca kvacid vādhakena apodyate iti ced liṅge pi evam iti tulyam
translated: And that is set aside in some cases by sublation. The same may be said of the mark.

original: tarhi prāmāṇyānumāne'pi śaṅkā tadavasthaiveti niṣphalaḥ prayāsa iti cet etadapi tādṛgeva /
analyzed: tarhi prāmāṇya anumāne api śaṅkā tad avasthā evā iti niṣphalaḥ prayāsaḥ iti ced etat api tādṛś eva
translated: If it is argued that even in the inference of validity, doubt remains in the same state, so the effort is fruitless, this too is similar.

original: anupapadyamānor'tha evāsau tathāvidhaḥ kaścit yaḥ svapne 'pi nābhāsaḥ syāt /
analyzed: anupapadyamāna ūrthaḥ eva asau tathāvidhaḥ kaścid yaḥ svapne na ābhāsaḥ syāt
translated: That which is not possible is of some such kind that it would not appear even in a dream.

original: tato nā'śaṅketi cet liṅge 'pyevamiti samaḥ samādhiḥ /
analyzed: tatas nā āśaṅkā iti ced liṅge pi evam iti samaḥ samādhiḥ
translated: If it is argued that therefore there is no doubt, the same applies to the inferential mark.

analyzed: kaḥ punar asau arthaḥ
translated: What, then, is that object?

analyzed: yaḥ svapne pi na ābhāsaḥ syāt  yad anupalambhe vibhrama avakāśaḥ
translated: That which would not appear even in a dream.🔽Where there is no perception, there is scope for error.

analyzed: yādṛś upalambhe ca tad bādha vyavasthā
translated: And where there is perception, there is the establishment of its contradiction.

original: anyathā hi tathābhūtasyāpi vyabhicāre sāpi na syāt /
analyzed: anyathā hi tathābhūtasya api vyabhicāre sā api na syāt
translated: Otherwise, even if it were of that nature, there would be no such [establishment] due to error.

original: mā bhūditi cenna bhavitavyaṃ hi tattvātatvavibhāgena tattvātattvavyavasthā
analyzed: mā bhūt iti ced na bhavitavyam hi tattva atatva vibhāgena tattva atattva vyavasthā
translated: If it is argued that it should not be so, it is said: it must be so, because of the distinction between reality and unreality. The distinction between reality and unreality is established by the distinction between real and unreal.

original: anyathā vyāghātāt /🔽kathaṃ hi niyāmakaniḥśeṣaviśeṣopalambhe 'pi viparītāropaḥ /🔽tathābhāve vā tadatiriktaviśeṣānupalambhe kathaṃ bādhakam /
analyzed: anyathā vyāghātāt  katham hi niyāmaka niḥśeṣa viśeṣa upalambhe viparīta āropaḥ  tathā abhāve vā tad atirikta viśeṣa anupalambhe katham bādhakam
translated: Otherwise, there would be a contradiction.🔽For how can there be an erroneous superimposition even when all the determining factors and particulars are perceived?🔽Or if it were so, how could there be a contradiction in the non-perception of particulars other than that?

analyzed: tad abhāve tu abādhasya katham bhrānta tvam iti
translated: But if that is absent, how can there be delusion in what is not contradicted?

analyzed: syāt etat paratas prāmāṇye pi nitya tvāt vedānām anapekṣa tvam
translated: Objection: Even if validity is extrinsic, the Vedas are eternal and independent.

analyzed: mahājana parigrahāt ca prāmāṇyam iti kaḥ virodhaḥ
translated: And their validity is due to the acceptance of the great people. What is the contradiction?

analyzed: na ubhayasya api asiddheḥ
translated: No. Because both are unestablished.

original: ku / / na hi varṇā eva tāvānnityaḥ /
analyzed: na hi varṇāḥ eva tāvān nityaḥ
translated: For the mere letters are not eternal to that extent.

original: tathā hi idānīṃ śrutapūrvo gakāro nāsti stīti
analyzed: tathā hi idānīm śruta pūrvaḥ gakāraḥ na asti sti iti
translated: Thus, the letter ga heard now is not there, it is not there.

original: nivṛttaḥ kolāhala iti pratyakṣeṇaiva śabdadhvaṃsaḥ pratīyate /
analyzed: nivṛttaḥ kolāhalaḥ iti pratyakṣeṇa eva śabda dhvaṃsaḥ pratīyate
translated: The destruction of sound is understood by perception itself, The tumult has ceased.

analyzed: na hi śabdaḥ eva anyatra gataḥ
translated: For the sound itself has not gone elsewhere.

analyzed: a mūrta tvāt
translated: Because it is incorporeal.

analyzed: na api āvṛtaḥ
translated: Nor is it covered.

analyzed: tatas eva sambandha viccheda anupapatteḥ
translated: Because the disconnection of the relation is not possible.

analyzed: na api anavahitaḥ śrotā
translated: Nor is the hearer inattentive.

analyzed: avadhāne pi anupalabdheḥ
translated: Because it is not perceived even in attention.

analyzed: na api indriyam duṣṭam
translated: Nor is the sense organ defective.

analyzed: śabda antara upalabdheḥ  na api sahakāri antara abhāvaḥ
translated: Because another sound is perceived.🔽Nor is there absence of a cooperating factor.

analyzed: anvaya vyatirekavataḥ kataḥ
translated: Because it is cognized by positive and negative concomitance.

analyzed: tasya asiddheḥ
translated: Because that is unestablished.

analyzed: na api atīndriyam
translated: Nor is it supersensible.

analyzed: tad kalpanāyām pramāṇa abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no evidence for imagining it.

analyzed: anyathā ghaṭa ādau api tad kalpanā prasaṅgāt  na ca śabdasya
translated: Otherwise, it would follow that it should be imagined even in a pot, etc.

analyzed: nitya tva siddhau tad kalpanā iti yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to imagine it when the eternality of sound is established.

analyzed: nirākariṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because it will be refuted.

original: ku / / yattvekadeśino naivamicchanti tān pratyucyate vivādādhyāsitaḥ śabdapradhvaṃsa indriyagrāhyaḥ aindriyikābhāvatvāt ghaṭābhāvavat
analyzed: yat tu ekadeśinaḥ na evam icchanti tān pratyucyate vivāda adhyāsitaḥ śabda pradhvaṃsaḥ indriya grāhyaḥ aindriyika abhāva tvāt ghaṭa abhāva vat
translated: But if some logicians do not accept this, then it is said to them: The destruction of sound, which is the subject of dispute, is perceptible by the senses, because it is an imperceptible absence, like the absence of a pot.

analyzed: na etat evam
translated: This is not so.

analyzed: indriya asannikṛṣṭa tvāt atīndriya ādhāra tvāt vā iti ced na idam hi upādhi udbhāvanam vā syāt
translated: If it is argued that it is not perceptible by the senses because it is not in contact with the senses, or because it has an imperceptible substratum, this is not so. For this would either be an assertion of a counter-reason,

analyzed: vyāpaka anupalabdhyā sat pratipakṣa tvam vā
translated: or it would be a counter-argument by the non-apprehension of the pervasion.

analyzed: na prathamaḥ
translated: Not the first.

analyzed: svarūpa yogyatām prati gyatāyām
translated: When there is fitness for the form,

analyzed: sahakāri yogyatāyāḥ anupādhi tvāt
translated: the fitness for auxiliaries is not a counter-reason,

analyzed: tasyāḥ tām apekṣya eva sarvadā vyavasthiteḥ
translated: because that is always established in dependence on it.

analyzed: na api aindriyika ādhāra tva prayuktam abhāvasya pratyakṣa tvam
translated: Nor is the perceptibility of absence due to having an imperceptible substratum.

analyzed: dharma ādi abhāvasya api tathātva prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that the absence of dharma, etc., would also be so.

analyzed: atas eva na ubhaya prayuktam
translated: For this very reason, it is not due to both.

analyzed: na api dvitīyaḥ
translated: Nor is the second.

analyzed: prathamasya asiddheḥ
translated: Because the first is unestablished.

analyzed: asti hi śrotra śabda abhāvayoḥ svābhāvikaḥ viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāvaḥ 🔽viśeṣyasya atīndriya tvāt katham aindriyika viśiṣṭa jñāna viṣaya tvam
translated: For there is a natural relation of qualifier and qualified between the ear and the absence of sound.🔽How can it be the object of a perception of something perceptible, when the qualified is imperceptible?

original: tathā viśeṣyamavyavasthāpayataśca kathaṃ viśeṣaṇatvamiti cet na /
analyzed: tathā viśeṣyam avyavasthāpayataḥ ca katham viśeṣaṇa tvam iti ced na
translated: If it be said that, in the same way, how can there be the relation of qualifier and qualified when the qualified is not determined? [We say] no.

analyzed: tathā viśeṣya vyavasthāpanāyāḥ phala tvāt
translated: Because the determination of the qualified is the effect [of the relation of qualifier and qualified].

analyzed: na tu tat eva viśeṣaṇa tvam
translated: But that itself is not the relation of qualifier and qualified.

analyzed: ātma āśraya prasaṅgāt viśeṣaṇa bhāvena samavāya abhāvayoḥ grahaṇam
translated: The relation of inherence is grasped by the relation of qualifier and qualified, because of the contingence of a regressus ad infinitum.

analyzed: tathā grahaṇam eva ca viśeṣaṇa tvam iti
translated: And the relation of qualifier and qualified is just the grasping in that way.

analyzed: tasmāt sambandha antaram antareṇa tad upaśliṣṭa svabhāva tvam eva hi tayoḥ
translated: Therefore, the mere nature of being conjoined with that is itself their relation, without any other relation.

analyzed: sā eva ca viśiṣṭa pratyaya janana yogya tā viśeṣaṇa tā iti ucyate
translated: And that very capacity to produce the cognition of the qualified is called the relation of qualifier and qualified.

analyzed: sā ca atra durnivārā  pratiyogi adhikaraṇena svabhāvataḥ eva abhāvasya
translated: And that is unavoidable here.

original: militatvāt /🔽ku / / tathāpi tayā tathaiva pratītiḥ kartavyeti cenna gṛhyamāṇaviśeṣyatvāvaṣyāva
analyzed: milita tvāt  tathā api tayā tathā eva pratītiḥ kartavyā iti ced na
translated: Because the absence, by its very nature, is united with the counter-correlate and the substratum.

analyzed: chinna tvāt vyāpteḥ
translated: Even so, if it be said that the cognition must be produced in that very way by that [capacity], no [we say]. Because the pervasion is necessarily restricted to the substratum that is grasped.

original: anyathā saṃyuktasamavāyena rūpādau viśiṣṭavikalpadhījananadarśanāt gandhādāvapi tathātvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: anyathā saṃyukta samavāyena rūpa ādau viśiṣṭa vikalpa dhī janana darśanāt gandha ādau api tathātva prasaṅgāt
translated: Otherwise, because the production of the cognition of the qualified is seen in color etc. by the relation of inherence with the conjoined [objects], it would follow that the same is the case with smell etc. as well.

original: ku / / tathāpi nendriyaviśeṣaṇatayā kasyacit grahaṇaṃ dṛṣṭam /
analyzed: tathā api na indriya viśeṣaṇa tayā kasyacid grahaṇam dṛṣṭam
translated: Even so, the grasping of anything by way of being a qualifier of a sense organ is not seen.

analyzed: api tu indriya sambaddha viśeṣaṇa tayā
translated: But rather by being a qualifier related to the sense organ.

original: sā cāto nivartata iti cenna asya pratibandhasyendriyasannikṛṣṭārthapratisambandhiviṣayatvāt /
analyzed: sā ca atas nivartate iti ced na asya pratibandhasya indriya sannikṛṣṭa artha pratisambandhi viṣaya tvāt
translated: And that is excluded from this [inference]. If it is argued that it is not so, because this relation is based on the object connected with the sense organ,

analyzed: anyathā saṃyukta samavāyena gandha ādau upalabdhi darśanāt samavāyena adarśanāt śabdasya agrahaṇa prasaṅgāt
translated: otherwise, because smell etc. are seen to be perceived by the relation of inherence with what is connected, there would be the undesirable consequence of non-apprehension of sound due to non-apprehension by inherence.

analyzed: na api abhāva tve sati atīndriya ādhāra tvāt sat pratipakṣa tvam
translated: Nor is there the counter-argument that it is an absence, because it has an imperceptible substratum.

analyzed: yogyatā viraha prayukta tvāt vyāpteḥ
translated: Because the pervasion is due to the absence of fitness.

analyzed: na ca atīndriya ādhāra tvam eva tasya yogyatā virahaḥ
translated: And the very having an imperceptible substratum is not the absence of fitness for it.

analyzed: tad viparyayasya eva yogyatā tva āpatteḥ
translated: Because the opposite of that itself becomes fitness.

analyzed: na ca evam eva
translated: And it is not so in this way.

analyzed: dharma ādi pradhvaṃsa grahaṇa prasaṅgāt
translated: Because there would be the undesirable consequence of the apprehension of the destruction of dharma etc.

original: dṛśyādhāratvaṃ dṛśyapratiyogitāceti dvayamapyasya yogyateti cenna ubhayanirūpaṇīyatvaniyamānabhyupagamāt /
analyzed: dṛśya ādhāra tvam dṛśya pratiyogitā ca iti dvayam api asya yogyatā iti ced na ubhaya nirūpaṇīya tva niyama anabhyupagamāt
translated: If it is argued that both - having a visible substratum and having a visible counter-correlate - are its fitness, it is not so, because the rule of being determined by both is not accepted.

analyzed: pratiyogi mātra nirūpaṇīyaḥ hi abhāvaḥ
translated: For absence is determined by the counter-correlate alone.

original: ku / / anyathā iha bhūtale ghaṭo nāstī'tyeṣāpi pratītiḥ pratyakṣā na syāt /
analyzed: anyathā iha bhū tale ghaṭaḥ na asti iti eṣā api pratītiḥ pratyakṣā na syāt
translated: Otherwise, this very cognition the pot does not exist on this ground would not be perception.

analyzed: saṃyogaḥ hi atra niṣidhyate
translated: For here conjunction is denied.

analyzed: tad abhāvaḥ ca bhū tala vat ghaṭe vartate
translated: And that absence occurs in the pot as well as in the ground.

analyzed: tatra yadi pratyakṣa tayā bhū talasya upayogaḥ
translated: If the ground is useful there by being perceived,

analyzed: ghaṭasya api tathā eva syāt
translated: the pot should be useful in the same way.

analyzed: aviśeṣāt
translated: Because there is no difference.

analyzed: atha ghaṭasya anyathā upayogaḥ
translated: But if the pot is useful in another way,

analyzed: bhū talasya api anyathā eva syāt aviśeṣāt
translated: the ground should be useful in another way too, because there is no difference.

analyzed: katham anyathā iti ced pratiyogi nirūpaṇa artham abhāva sannikarṣa artham ca  tatra pratiyogi nirūpaṇam smaraṇa lakṣaṇam anupalabhyamānena api iti
translated: If it is asked how in another way, [it is] for the purpose of determining the counter-correlate and for the purpose of the proximity of absence.🔽There, the determination of the counter-correlate is characterized by recollection, even when it is not perceived.

analyzed: na tad artham adhyakṣa gocara tvam apekṣaṇīyam anyatarasya api
translated: Therefore, the state of being the object of perception is not to be expected for the purpose of that by either of the two.

analyzed: kutas ubhayasya
translated: How much less for both.

analyzed: sannikarṣaḥ tu bhū tala ghaṭa saṃyoga abhāvasya indriyeṇa sākṣāt na asti
translated: But there is no direct proximity of the sense organ with the absence of the conjunction of the ground and the pot.

analyzed: yena asti tena api yadi indriyam na sannikṛṣyeta
translated: By what there is, if the sense organ were not brought into proximity,

analyzed: katham iva tam gamayet
translated: how could it make that known?

analyzed: na ca upalabdha upalabhyamānābhyām eva indriyam sannikṛṣyate
translated: And the sense organ is not brought into proximity only with what is perceived and what is being perceived,

analyzed: itaretara āśraya prasaṅgāt
translated: because of the contingence of mutual dependence.

original: ku / / tasmāt sannikarṣe sati yogyatvāt bhūtalamapyupalabhyate /
analyzed: tasmāt sannikarṣe sati yogya tvāt bhū talam api upalabhyate
translated: Therefore, when there is proximity, because of fitness, the ground is also perceived.

analyzed: na tu tasya upalabhyamāna tvam abhāva upalabdheḥ aṅgam iti yuktam utpaśyāmaḥ
translated: But we do not see how the perception of it can be a part of the perception of non-existence.

original: prakṛte tu na pratiyoginirūpaṇārthaṃ tadupayogaḥ tasya saṃyogavat ādhārānirūpyatvāt /
analyzed: prakṛte tu na pratiyogi nirūpaṇa artham tad upayogaḥ tasya saṃyoga vat ādhāra anirūpya tvāt
translated: But in the present case, its use is not for the purpose of determining the counter-correlate, because it is not dependent on a substratum like conjunction.

analyzed: na api sannikarṣa artham
translated: Nor is it for the purpose of contact.

analyzed: tad abhāvasya sākṣāt indriya sannikarṣāt iti
translated: Because its absence is in direct contact with the sense organ.

analyzed: na ced evam
translated: If it is not so,

original: kuta eṣā pratītiḥ /🔽idānīṃ śrutapūrvaḥ śabdo nāstīti /
analyzed: kutas eṣā pratītiḥ  idānīm śruta pūrvaḥ śabdaḥ na asti iti
translated: from where is this cognition?🔽That the sound heard before is not now.

analyzed: anumānāt iti ced na śabdasya eva pakṣīkaraṇe
translated: If it is said to be by inference, no, because in making sound itself the subject,

analyzed: hetoḥ anāśraya tvāt

analyzed: anitya tva mātra sādhane bhāvasya niyata kāla tva asiddheḥ
translated: If only impermanence is established, the absence is not established as having a fixed time.

analyzed: ākāśasya pakṣa tve tadvat tayā anupalabhyamāna tvasya hetoḥ anaikāntika tvāt
translated: If space is the subject, then the reason of not being perceived as having that property is inconclusive,

analyzed: śabda sadbhāva kāle pi tasya sattvāt
translated: because it exists even at the time when sound exists.

analyzed: evam kāla pakṣe pi doṣāt
translated: In the same way, there is a fault even if time is the subject.

original: ku / / ahamidānīṃ niḥśabdaśrotravān śabdopalabdhirahitatvāt badhiravaditi cetnadṛṣṭāntasya sādhyavikalatvāt /
analyzed: aham idānīm niḥśabda śrotravān śabda upalabdhi rahita tvāt badhira vat iti cetna dṛṣṭāntasya sādhya vikala tvāt
translated: If it is said that I now have a soundless ear, because I am devoid of the perception of sound, like a deaf person, no, because the example lacks what is to be proven.

analyzed: vyāhata tvāt ca
translated: And because it is contradictory.

analyzed: badhiraḥ ca śrotravān ca iti vyāhatam
translated: It is contradictory to say one is both deaf and has ears.

original: tasyāpi ca śravaso niḥśabdatve pramāṇaṃ nāsti /
analyzed: tasya api ca śravasaḥ niḥśabda tve pramāṇam na asti
translated: And there is no proof that that sound is also soundless.

analyzed: anupabhogyasya utpāda vaiyarthyam pramāṇam iti cetna ādi ādi śabda vat upapatteḥ
translated: If it is argued that the proof is the uselessness of the production of what is not experienced, it is not so, because it is possible like the word beginning etc.

analyzed: teṣām śabda antara ārambham pratyupayogaḥ
translated: They are useful for the production of another sound.

analyzed: antyasya na tathā iti ced na antya tva asiddheḥ

analyzed: sarveṣām ca utpādavatām prayojana tad abhāvayoḥ asmādṛśaiḥ an ākalanāt
translated: And because by people like us the purpose and its absence of all that is produced cannot be ascertained.

analyzed: suṣupti avasthāyām śvāsa praśvāsa prayojana vat ca tad upapatteḥ
translated: And because it is possible like the purpose of inhalation and exhalation in the state of deep sleep.

analyzed: ārambhe sati prayojanam avaśyam iti vyāpteḥ
translated: Because there is the pervasion that when there is production, there must be a purpose.

analyzed: na tu āpātataḥ prayojana anupalambha mātreṇa ārambha nivṛttiḥ
translated: But it is not that the production ceases merely by the non-apprehension of the purpose at first.

original: tathā sati karṇaśaṣkulyavacchedotpāda eva nabhasastaṃ prati nivarteta /
analyzed: tathā sati karṇa śaṣkulī avaccheda utpādaḥ eva nabhasaḥ tam prati nivarteta
translated: If it were so, then the production of the space enclosed by the cavity of the ear itself would cease in regard to it.

analyzed: badhirasya tena anupayogāt  vivāda kāle badhira karṇaḥ śabdavān
translated: Because it is not useful to the deaf.

analyzed: sthāna āvṛta karṇa śaṣkulī suṣira tvāt tad itara karṇa śaṣkulī suṣira vat iti
translated: At the time of dispute, the deaf ear is endowed with sound, because it is the cavity of the ear in a suitable place and space, like the cavity of the ear of another which is not so.

analyzed: niḥśabdāḥ paṇava vīṇā veṇavaḥ
translated: The kettledrums, lutes and flutes are soundless.

analyzed: tad eka jñāna saṃsarga yogya tve sati tad anupalambhe pi upalabhyamāna tvāt  yat
translated: Because even when that is not perceived, it is perceived, when it is fit to be associated with a single cognition.

analyzed: yogyaṃya
translated: Whatever is fit to be associated with a single cognition

analyzed: tasya anupalambhe pi upalabhyate tat tad abhāvavat
translated: when that is not perceived, and yet is perceived, it is as if that were absent.

analyzed: yathā aghaṭam bhū talam iti ced na eka jñāna saṃsarga yogya tva abhāvāt
translated: If it is argued that it is like a pot on the ground, no, because there is no fitness to be associated with a single cognition.

analyzed: śabdasya śrauta tvāt
translated: Because sound is audible,

analyzed: vīṇā ādīnām cākṣuṣa tvāt
translated: and because the veena etc. are visible.

analyzed: abhimāna mātrāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that it is merely a conceit, no.

analyzed: tathā api śabda pradhvaṃsasya a tad deśa tvāt
translated: Even so, because the destruction of sound is not in that place.

analyzed: atyanta abhāvasya ca kāla niyamāt
translated: And because absolute non-existence is restricted to time.

analyzed: syāt etat śabdavat ākāśa upādhayaḥ hi bherī ādayaḥ
translated: It may be argued that the drums etc. are the limiting adjuncts of space, like sound.

original: tena teṣu vidhīyamānaḥ śabdaḥ ākāśa eva vihito bhavati /
analyzed: tena teṣu vidhīyamānaḥ śabdaḥ ākāśe eva vihitaḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, when sound is enjoined in them, it is enjoined in space itself.

analyzed: pratiṣiddhyamānaḥ ca tatra eva pratiṣiddhaḥ bhavati
translated: And when it is prohibited, it is prohibited there itself.

original: śarīre sukhādivat iti cet na tatra sopādhāvātmani pratyakṣasiddhe sukhādiniṣedhasyāpi pratyakṣāsiddhatvāt /
analyzed: śarīre sukha ādi vat iti ced na tatra sa upādhau ātmani pratyakṣa siddhe sukha ādi niṣedhasya api pratyakṣa asiddha tvāt
translated: If it is argued that it is like pleasure etc. in the body, no, because even the prohibition of pleasure etc. is not established by perception, in the self that is established by perception along with its limiting adjuncts there.

analyzed: na ca evam iha api
translated: And it is not so here.

analyzed: tad upahitasya nabhasaḥ pratyakṣa tvāt
translated: Because the sky limited by that is not perceptible.

analyzed: upādhayaḥ tāvat pratyakṣāḥ iti ced na taiḥ abhāva anirūpaṇāt
translated: If it be said that the adjuncts are perceived, we deny this, because non-existence is not defined by them.

analyzed: nirūpaṇe vā pratyakṣeṇa api grahaṇa prasaṅgāt
translated: Or, if it were defined, it would follow that it is perceived by perception.

analyzed: na ca evam sati pāramārthika adhikaraṇa nirūpaṇīya tvam abhāvasya
translated: And in that case, non-existence is not really defined by the substratum.

analyzed: na ca te pi pratyakṣa siddhāḥ  sarvatra śabda kāraṇa vyavadhāne pi upalabdhasya
translated: And those [adjuncts] are not established by perception everywhere,

analyzed: śabdasya na astitā pratīteḥ
translated: because the non-existence of sound is perceived even when there is an obstruction to the cause of sound.

analyzed: ānumānikaiḥ taiḥ tathā vyavahāraḥ iti ced na hetoḥ tadvat tayā anupalabhyamāna tvasya anaikāntika tvāt  abhāva pratīti kāle sandigdha āśraya tvāt ca
translated: If it be said that the usage [of non-existence] is by those [adjuncts] inferred, we deny this, because the reason, being unperceived as such, is inconclusive.🔽And because the substratum is doubtful at the time of the cognition of non-existence.

analyzed: upalabhyamāna viśeṣya tva pakṣe ca asiddheḥ

analyzed: dravya guṇa tva pariśeṣe saṃyoga samavāyayoḥ anyataraḥ sambandhaḥ iti ced na bādhaka balena

analyzed: tasmāt eka deśa pariśeṣaḥ na pramāṇam

analyzed: sandeha saṅkoca mātra hetu tvāt

analyzed: atha dravya tve kim bādhakam

analyzed: iti pariśeṣāt guṇa tvena  samavāyiya

analyzed: ca asiddhena sat pratipakṣa tvam

analyzed: asiddhasya hīna bala tvāt
translated: Because what is unestablished is of lesser strength.

analyzed: nanu
translated: How? Indeed, sound is not at all

analyzed: śrotra guṇaḥ nā evā iti tvayā eva sādhitam prabandhena

analyzed: na ca śrotra guṇaḥ

analyzed: tena gṛhyamāṇa tvāt

analyzed: yat yena indriyeṇa gṛhyate

analyzed: na asau tasya guṇaḥ

analyzed: yathā gṛhyamāṇaḥ gandha ādiḥ
translated: Like smell and so on that are grasped.

analyzed: na ca etat api

analyzed: ghrāṇa ādi samaveta gandha ādi agrahe sva guṇa tvasya aprayojaka tvāt

analyzed: hi tatra upādhiḥ

original: ku / / anyathā sukhādirnātmaguṇaḥ tena gṛhyamāṇatvāt rūpādivat /

analyzed: na vā tena gṛhyate tad samaveta tvāt adṛṣṭa vat

translated: So what is unreasonable here?

analyzed: grahaṇāt

analyzed: na ca dravya viśeṣa grahaṇe tad upayogaḥ
translated: And it is not of use in the perception of a specific substance.

analyzed: viśeṣa guṇa yogya tām āśritya eva indriyasya dravya grāhaka tvāt

analyzed: na dravya svarūpa yogya tā mātreṇa

analyzed: an udbhūta rūpe vā cakṣuḥ pravartate

analyzed: tasmāt guṇa yogya tām eva puraskṛtya indriyāṇi dravyam upādadate

analyzed: na atas nyathā iti sthitiḥ

analyzed: atas eva na ākāśa ādayaḥ cākṣuṣāḥ  astu tarhi śabdaḥ nityaḥ  guṇa tvāt

analyzed: anyathā

analyzed: asya pratyakṣa bādhita tvāt ahetu tvam iti ced na nirupādheḥ bādhā anavakāśāt

analyzed: svabhāva pratibaddhasya ca tad parityāge svabhāva parityāga prasaṅgāt

analyzed: tasmāt bādhena vā upādhiḥ unnīyate
translated: Therefore, either non-eternality is established by contradiction, or it is established by a reason.

analyzed: anyathā vā iti na kaścid viśeṣaḥ
translated: There is no difference [between the two].

analyzed: etena śrāvaṇa tvāt śabda tva vat iti api parāstam
translated: By this [argument], the inference that sound is non-eternal because it is audible, like a pot, is also refuted.

analyzed: atrā api tasya eva upādhi tvāt

analyzed: anyathā gandha rūpa rasa sparśāḥ api nityāḥ prasajyeran
translated: Otherwise, smell, form, taste, and touch would also be eternal,

translated: Here, contradiction and non-pervasion are impossible, so non-establishment remains.

analyzed: sā api na asti

analyzed: tathā hi śabdaḥ tāvat
translated: To explain: Sound, first of all,

translated: If the cloth were to perish only after contact with the destroyer, like before contact with saffron,

analyzed: yathā hi vināśa kāraṇam vinā na vināśaḥ

translated: If it is argued that the universal alone is the meaning of a word,

analyzed: kim ākṣepeṇa

analyzed: vinā jāti viṣaya tā tasya anupa tā anupa
translated: But without the object of the manifestation, the object of the universal is not possible,

analyzed: pannā iti ced na evam tarhi eka jñāna gocara tāyām kim anupapannam

analyzed: kim pratipādayet iti

translated: If it be said that the non-occurrence of anything else is the evidence here, because it is accepted by the majority, we reply: No,🔽because if it is possible by the mere supposition of such a thing, the assumption of many things would lead to the fault of prolixity.

analyzed: videha nirmāṇa śkteḥ aṇima ādi vibhūteḥ ca avaśya abhyupagantavya tvāt
translated: And because the power of creating a body without material cause and the power of becoming atomic, etc. must necessarily be accepted.

original: astveka eveti cet na tarhīśvaramantareṇānyatra samāśvāsa iti /🔽ku / / kāraṃ kāramalaukikādbhutamayaṃ māyāvaśāt saṃharan /

translated: If it be said that there may be only one, we reply: Then there can be no comfort anywhere else except in God.🔽The Lord, withdrawing the wonderful and marvelous creation of the world by His Maya,

original: hāraṃ hāramapīndrajālamiva yaḥ kurvan jagatkrīḍati //🔽taṃ devaṃ niravagrahasphuradabhidhyānānubhāvaṃ bhavam /

translated: as if withdrawing a necklace, a necklace, and creating the world again, plays with it.🔽I bow to that God Bhava, whose power of meditation shines without restraint,

analyzed: viśvāsa eka bhuvam śivam prati naman
translated: and who is the sole support of faith, the auspicious one.

analyzed: bhūyāsam antyeṣu api
